title: Premier Inn guest greeted by 'Welcome t***' message on his TV
text:
2
View
comments
Premier Inn has apologised and reimbursed a guest who says he was greeted by an obscene welcome message when he turned on the TV in his room.
Phil Burke claims ‘Welcome t***’ was displayed on the screen when he arrived at the budget chain’s hotel in Dartford, Kent.
He was so insulted by the message he demanded an apology from the hotel, and the cost of his stay was reimbursed after he continued to make a number of complaints about his stay.
‘Welcome t***’ was displayed on the screen when Phil Burke arrived at a Premier Inn in Dartford, Kent
Mr Burke tweeted Premier Inn after he was confronted by the subtitle, writing: ‘Would you like to explain this greeting I have just received??? Very nice. I’m sure you’ll agree.’
After no responses and nine tweets, he posted again: ‘Does anyone there care to comment on this disgusting message on my hotel TV? I can’t express how disappointed I am.’
A Premier Inn employee responded the following day, writing: ‘Oh dear Phil! So sorry about this. Have you spoke to a team member at all?’

Mr Burke explained that he reported the message to a staff member at the three-star hotel’s reception desk, but ‘there was little he could do’.
He added: ‘How on earth can you allow this to happen in the first place? I'm absolutely disgusted’.
Responding via Twitter, an employee apologised and said an investigation would take place to determine how the message wound up on his TV screen.
Premier Inn says a 'full investigation' is underway after the incident at its Dartford location (pictured)
After he was asked how the rest of his stay went, Mr Burke blasted the hotel chain: ‘My stay was awful. Scaffolding outside my window and a nice view of a pylon, uncomfortable bed and my starter and main meal did not come as advertised.
‘Possibly the worst experience I've ever had at a hotel. Awful experience’.
Yet he has drawn criticism for his outburst, with one Twitter user telling him: ‘It’s a Premier Inn not the Dorchester.’
A Premier Inn spokeswoman said: ‘We take all complaints very seriously and a full investigation into how this occurred is underway.
‘We apologise for any offence caused and Mr Burke's stay has now been refunded.
‘We are pleased that he has also accepted our offer of a complimentary overnight stay at one of our hotels in the UK.’
MailOnline Travel has contacted Mr Burke for comment.
Meanwhile, a businessman claims the towels and bed sheets in his £100 room at a Premier Inn had not been changed following the departure of the previous guest.
Lee Green, 29, said he was confronted with a bed that had just been slept in, litter and damp towels at the Bricket Wood hotel, in St Albans, Hertfordshire.
The sales manager, from Gosport, Hampshire, claims that there was just one member of staff on shift who told him that there were no cleaners working and no spare rooms so he would have to sleep in the used bed.
A Premier Inn spokesperson said its housekeeping staff go through ‘extensive training’ and ‘experiences such as these are extremely rare’.
Mr Green’s stay was refunded and he was offered a free overnight stay and breakfast at any Premier Inn hotel in the UK.
